posts.title: ELI5: Why Do Programs Forget to Clean Up After Themselves?
posts.description: Your computer has a janitor that cleans up trash. But some things need to be thrown away immediately. Here's why programs leak memory ‚Äî explained with restaurants and dishes.
posts.linkedInHook:
Why do programs leak memory?

Imagine running a restaurant kitchen. When customers finish eating, dirty dishes pile up.

Option 1: Stack them and wait for the dishwasher to clean them in bulk
Option 2: Wash each dish immediately

Most programming languages work like Option 1. They have a "dishwasher" called the garbage collector (GC).

That works great... until you get really busy.

Customers keep coming. Dishes keep piling up. The dishwasher can't keep up.

Eventually, you run out of clean dishes. The kitchen grinds to a halt.

This is a memory leak.

In programming, there are two types of trash:

1. Regular trash (memory) - Paper plates. Can wait for the GC.
2. Special trash (resources) - Dishes with food still on them. Need immediate cleanup.

File handles, network connections, database connections ‚Äî these are "dishes." If you don't clean them immediately, you run out.

The fix: Explicit cleanup. In C#, that's `using` statements.

Our production leak: We forgot to "wash our dishes" for 2 years. Five `using` statements fixed it.

The dishwasher isn't magic. Sometimes you have to wash your own dishes.

posts.title: IDisposable: What I Misunderstood for 30 Years
posts.description: Objects don't dispose themselves when they go out of scope. I believed they did. For three decades. Here's why C# works this way ‚Äî and why it matters.
posts.linkedInHook:
After 30 years of C# development, I just learned that objects don't dispose themselves when they go out of scope.

I thought they did. So did most developers I know.

Quick quiz: What happens when this method exits?

```csharp
void ProcessData()
{
    var stream = new FileStream("data.txt", FileMode.Open);
    var reader = new StreamReader(stream);
    var content = reader.ReadToEnd();
    // Are stream and reader disposed here?
}
```

If you answered "yes," you're wrong. And you're in good company.

What actually happens:
‚úÖ Local variables go out of scope (stack cleanup)
‚úÖ References to objects removed
‚ùå Objects themselves NOT disposed
‚ùå File handles remain open
‚è∞ Eventually GC collects them
üî• Or you run out of file handles first

C# has three types of cleanup:
1. Stack cleanup (automatic, immediate)
2. Heap cleanup (automatic, eventually)
3. Resource cleanup (manual, explicit)

The fix: `using` statements. Always.

One misconception. Two years of production leaks.
